Name.BusinessNameLine1: THE WILLIAM A FARNSWORTH LIBRARY AND ART

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: THE MUSEUM'S MISSION IS TO CELEBRATE MAINE'S ROLE IN AMERICAN ART. TO ACCOMPLISH THAT MISSION THE MUSEUM PROVIDES AN EXTENSIVE OFFERING OF COLLECTIONS, EXHIBITIONS, EDUCATION AND RETAIL SERVICES TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC.
IRS990.MissionDescription: THE MUSEUM'S MISSION IS TO CELEBRATE MAINE'S ROLE IN AMERICAN ART. TO ACCOMPLISH THAT MISSION THE MUSEUM PROVIDES AN EXTENSIVE OFFERING OF COLLECTIONS, EXHIBITIONS, EDUCATION AND RETAIL SERVICES TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

Activity2.Description: EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMINGIn 2010, the Education Department brought to Maine several preeminent speakers from the world of art. Established several years ago, The Farnsworth Forum is an annual lecture series that arranges for America's leading public intellectuals to speak in Rockland. In the summer, the Director of the Metropolitan Opera Peter Gelb spoke on the current state of opera in New York and around the globe. In the fall, art historian and author of the major publication, "American Encounters: Art, History, and Cultural Identity" Angela Miller gave her view of the future of American and global art.As well as conducting the always-popular Achieving American Art in the spring, the Education Department organized two, three-part lecture series in the fall. "American Picturesque" focused on our country's landscape culture in the mid-nineteenth century and drew a large audience in the Farnsworth auditorium. "On Beauty & Beyond" examined the concept of beauty as represented in world art and was conducted in The Strand Theatre.The Education Department expanded its offering for youth and adults throughout 2010. The variety of art-making classes can be seen in the following list of selections: linoleum block printing, mixed media portraiture, gouache painting, figure drawing, encaustic workshop, and Japanese style printmaking.The Education Department continued and strengthened various and sundry partnerships, including those with The Strand Theatre, Camden Conference, Peche Kucha, Maine Media Workshops and the surrounding public school districts. The major partnership established in 2010 was the strategic alliance with Lincoln Center Institute, New York. Lincoln Center Institute is the education arm of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc., the best-known and largest cultural institution in the world. Going forward, for one week in July, the Farnsworth will team up with Lincoln Center Institute to offer teachers form around the country a fully accredited workshop in aesthetic education.Julia's Gallery for Young Artists broke new artistic ground with the production of "The Roaring 20s." Julia's Gallery middle and high school students wrote, created the sets, handled the lighting and filming, and acted in a music video on the 1920s. The entire video was shot on a HD i-Phone and presented before over 300 people in The Strand Theatre in November.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Part V, Line 4: Intended uses of the endowment fund.
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: THE PURPOSE OF THESE FUNDS IS TO GENERATE INCOME TO BE USED TO HELP MEET THE OPERATING AND NON-OPERATING COSTS OF THE MUSEUM.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Part III, Line 4: Description of organization's collections and how it furthers its purpose.
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION AMOUNTS TO MORE THAN 10,000 WORKS OF ART FROM THE NINETEENTH CENTURY TO THE PRESENT OF ARTISTS WHO LIVED OR WORKED IN MAINE. THE COLLECTION FURTHERS THE MUSEUM'S CHARITABLE, SCIENTIFIC, LITERARY AND EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES INCLUDING MANAGING AND OPERATING THE MUSEUM AND HOMESTEAD LOCATED IN ROCKLAND, MAINE AND THE OLSON HOUSE IN CUSHING, MAINE. THE MUSEUM'S MISSION IS TO "CELEBRATE MAINE'S ROLE IN AMERICAN ART." HOLDINGS IN THE COLLECTION INCLUDE PAINTINGS BY JONATHAN FISHER, FITZ HENRY LANE, THOMAS MORAN, CHILDE HASSAM, FRANK BENSON, ROBERT HENRI, GEORGE BELLOWS, ROCKWELL KENT, MARSDEN HARTLET, N.C. WYETH, ANDREW WYETH, JAIME WYETH, MARGUERITE ZORACH, JOHN MARIN, LOUISE NEVELSON, ALEX KATZ, ROBERT INDIANA; AND PHOTOGRAPHS BY BERENICE ABBIT, ELLIOT PORTER, PAUL CAPONIGRO, GEORGE TICE, AMONG OTHERS.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Part III, Line 1a: If organization elected under SFAS 116 to not report are, historical treasures, o
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: THE VALUE OF THE LIBRARY AND ART COLLECTIONS HELD BY THE MUSEUM IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE ACCOMPANYING FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. PURCHASES OF COLLECTION ITEMS ARE MADE FROM PROCEEDS OF DEACCESSIONS AND GIFTS OF CASH AND INCOME FROM CERTAIN TRUSTS RESTRICTED BY DONORS FOR ART AQUISITIONS. THE COLLECTION OF THE MUSEUM CONSISTS OF APPROXIMATELY 10,000 OBJECTS INCLUDING PAINTINGS, WATERCOLORS, SCULPTURE, PRINTS, DRAWINGS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND HISTORICAL ARTIFACTS (PRIMARILY RELATED TO THE HOMESTEAD). CONSISTENT WITH THE MUSEUM'S MISSION STATEMENT, THE COLLECTION EMPHASIZES WORKS BY AMERICAN ARTISTS, ESPECIALLY ARTISTS WHO HAVE WORKED IN MAINE. AS A WHOLE, THE COLLECTION PRESENTS A SURVEY OF MAINE'S ROLE IN THE HISTORY OF AMERICAN ART FROM THE LATE 18TH CENTURY TO THE PRESENT. THE MUSEUM CONTINUES TO ACTIVELY COLLECT AMERICAN ART THROUGH PURCHASE AND GIFTS. ALL WORKS IN THE PERMANENT COLLECTION ARE ASSIGNED A UNIQUE "ACCESSION" NUMBER AND PLACED IN SECURE STOAGE WHEN NOT ON EXHIBIT AT THE MUSEUM OR ON LAON TO OTHER MUSEUMS. THE MUSEUM ONLY LENDS TO GALLERIES AND MUSEUMS THAT MEET PRESCRIBED SECURITY AND CLIMATE STANDARDS AND PROVIDE ALL RISK INSURANCE CONVERAGE. RECORDS, INCLUDING OBJECT, ARTIST AND DONOR FILES, ARE MAINTAINED FOR EACH WORK OF ART. THE COLLECTION IS SPOT INVENTORIED ANNUALLY BY STAFF AND QUALIFIED CONSERVATORS ASSIST AS NECESSARY. THE MUSEUM MAINTAINS A BLANKET INSURANCE POLICY OF $60 MILLION FOR THE COLLECTION AND WORK ON LOAN. ALTHOUGH A PRIVATE, INDEPENDENT INSTITUTION, THE COLLECTION IS MAINTAINED, ADDED TO, EXHIBITED AND INTERPRETED FOR THE EDUCATION AND ENJOYMENT OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19: Other Organization Documents Publicly Available
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE 990 IS POSTED ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE. CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY AND GOVERNING DOCUMENTS ARE MADE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE ANNUAL REPORT, WHICH IS PROVIDED UPON REQUEST. BEGINNING IN 2010, THE ANNUAL REPORT WILL BE POSTED TO THE MUSEUM'S WEB SITE

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b: Compensation Review and Approval Process for Officers and Key Employees
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: BOARD OF TRUSTEES ARE VOLUNTEERS. THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES DETERMINES THE COMPENSATION OF THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR USING MARKET VALUE COMPARISONS AND DATA FROM THE AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF MUSEUM'S SALARY SURVEY. THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR DETERMINES COMPENSATION OF OTHER OFFICERS USING THE SAME PROCESS. THIS PROCESS WAS LAST PERFORMED IN DECEMBER 2009.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c: Explanation of Monitoring and Enforcement of Conflicts
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE POLICY, BOARD MEMBERS ARE REQUIRED TO SIGN AN ANNUAL CONFLICT OF INTEREST DISCLOSURE AND TO REPORT TO THE PRESIDENT ANY CONFLICTS THAT ARISE DURING THE YEAR.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11: Form 990 Review Process
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE 990 IS REVIEWED BY THE FINANCE COMMITTEE WITH FINAL REVIEW AND APPROVAL GIVEN BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE PRIOR TO FILING.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 2: Description of Business or Family Relationship of Officers, Directors, Et
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: TWO BOARD MEMBERS ARE RELATED - BROTHER/SISTER-IN-LAW.
